What I Automated This Week â€” and Saved 2 Hours WeeklyOne of my personal goals as a DevOps engineer is to eliminate repetitive manual tasks â€” not just for myself, but for the whole team.This week I automated something small, but annoying: âŒ manually building Docker images âŒ logging into the registry âŒ pushing images âŒ double-checking version tagsNow, GitLab CI does it all for me: âœ… automatically builds Docker images âœ… logs into the private registry using GitLab CI secrets âœ… pushes images on merge or tag âœ… tags them using git describe + commit hashWhat did I get from this? ğŸ•’ saved around 2 hours per week âœ… less chance to miss a step ğŸš€ it's set-and-forget â€” I just push, and it fliesBonus tips that helped me: - use rules: to run only on merge to main - use before_script to log in securely with secrets - use CI_COMMIT_TAG and CI_COMMIT_REF_NAME for dynamic versioningIf you're interested, I can share a full .gitlab-ci.yml snippet with comments and tricks I use.ğŸ’¬ Whatâ€™s the last thing you automated that made your life easier? Even small changes can save you hours â€” share yours!

What I Automated This Week â€” and Saved 2 Hours WeeklyOne of my personal goals as a DevOps engineer is to eliminate repetitive manual tasks â€” not just for myself, but for the whole team.This week I automated something small, but annoying: âŒ manually building Docker images âŒ logging into the registry âŒ pushing images âŒ double-checking version tagsNow, GitLab CI does it all for me: âœ… automatically builds Docker images âœ… logs into the private registry using GitLab CI secrets âœ… pushes images on merge or tag âœ… tags them using git describe + commit hashWhat did I get from this? ğŸ•’ saved around 2 hours per week âœ… less chance to miss a step ğŸš€ it's set-and-forget â€” I just push, and it fliesBonus tips that helped me: - use rules: to run only on merge to main - use before_script to log in securely with secrets - use CI_COMMIT_TAG and CI_COMMIT_REF_NAME for dynamic versioningIf you're interested, I can share a full .gitlab-ci.yml snippet with comments and tricks I use.ğŸ’¬ Whatâ€™s the last thing you automated that made your life easier? Even small changes can save you hours â€” share yours!

What I Automated This Week â€” and Saved 2 Hours WeeklyOne of my personal goals as a DevOps engineer is to eliminate repetitive manual tasks â€” not just for myself, but for the whole team.This week I automated something small, but annoying: âŒ manually building Docker images âŒ logging into the registry âŒ pushing images âŒ double-checking version tagsNow, GitLab CI does it all for me: âœ… automatically builds Docker images âœ… logs into the private registry using GitLab CI secrets âœ… pushes images on merge or tag âœ… tags them using git describe + commit hashWhat did I get from this? ğŸ•’ saved around 2 hours per week âœ… less chance to miss a step ğŸš€ it's set-and-forget â€” I just push, and it fliesBonus tips that helped me: - use rules: to run only on merge to main - use before_script to log in securely with secrets - use CI_COMMIT_TAG and CI_COMMIT_REF_NAME for dynamic versioningIf you're interested, I can share a full .gitlab-ci.yml snippet with comments and tricks I use.ğŸ’¬ Whatâ€™s the last thing you automated that made your life easier? Even small changes can save you hours â€” share yours!

What I Automated This Week â€” and Saved 2 Hours WeeklyOne of my personal goals as a DevOps engineer is to eliminate repetitive manual tasks â€” not just for myself, but for the whole team.This week I automated something small, but annoying: âŒ manually building Docker images âŒ logging into the registry âŒ pushing images âŒ double-checking version tagsNow, GitLab CI does it all for me: âœ… automatically builds Docker images âœ… logs into the private registry using GitLab CI secrets âœ… pushes images on merge or tag âœ… tags them using git describe + commit hashWhat did I get from this? ğŸ•’ saved around 2 hours per week âœ… less chance to miss a step ğŸš€ it's set-and-forget â€” I just push, and it fliesBonus tips that helped me: - use rules: to run only on merge to main - use before_script to log in securely with secrets - use CI_COMMIT_TAG and CI_COMMIT_REF_NAME for dynamic versioningIf you're interested, I can share a full .gitlab-ci.yml snippet with comments and tricks I use.ğŸ’¬ Whatâ€™s the last thing you automated that made your life easier? Even small changes can save you hours â€” share yours!

Here's why you must be careful of wanting to land a remote job?Many persons desire to work form home,infact we now see it as a flex.I mean, you can be in your PJ, with your juice by the side... yet you're doing the work.isn't that great?Well in reality, it's not always like that.Working from home requires discipline, motivation, and a lot more.-Can you stay motivated and focused without direct supervision?- Are you comfortable with minimal social interaction and human connection?- Can you establish clear boundaries between work and personal life?Ask Yourself all these before wanting a remote job.ğŸ”¹ï¸Now to my 9-5 workersThat you do the everyday 9-5 job does not make you a failure.There are people who thrive more in the on-site work place and others in remote jobs.The most important thing is to give your best, explore your full potential and make the most of the opportunity you have.Things to look out for whether Remote or on-site. 1ï¸âƒ£Taking ownership of your work and projects2ï¸âƒ£Comfort, make sure you're happy doing your job, if not please take neccessary actions.3ï¸âƒ£Work-life balance,  Easily balance work and personal responsibilities, improving overall well-being and not burn out.If we all know this, everyone will be happy to make the most of what they have currently. What I Automated This Week â€” and Saved 2 Hours WeeklyOne of my personal goals as a DevOps engineer is to eliminate repetitive manual tasks â€” not just for myself, but for the whole team.This week I automated something small, but annoying: âŒ manually building Docker images âŒ logging into the registry âŒ pushing images âŒ double-checking version tagsNow, GitLab CI does it all for me: âœ… automatically builds Docker images âœ… logs into the private registry using GitLab CI secrets âœ… pushes images on merge or tag âœ… tags them using git describe + commit hashWhat did I get from this? ğŸ•’ saved around 2 hours per week âœ… less chance to miss a step ğŸš€ it's set-and-forget â€” I just push, and it fliesBonus tips that helped me: - use rules: to run only on merge to main - use before_script to log in securely with secrets - use CI_COMMIT_TAG and CI_COMMIT_REF_NAME for dynamic versioningIf you're interested, I can share a full .gitlab-ci.yml snippet with comments and tricks I use.ğŸ’¬ Whatâ€™s the last thing you automated that made your life easier? Even small changes can save you hours â€” share yours!

Here's why you must be careful of wanting to land a remote job?Many persons desire to work form home,infact we now see it as a flex.I mean, you can be in your PJ, with your juice by the side... yet you're doing the work.isn't that great?Well in reality, it's not always like that.Working from home requires discipline, motivation, and a lot more.-Can you stay motivated and focused without direct supervision?- Are you comfortable with minimal social interaction and human connection?- Can you establish clear boundaries between work and personal life?Ask Yourself all these before wanting a remote job.ğŸ”¹ï¸Now to my 9-5 workersThat you do the everyday 9-5 job does not make you a failure.There are people who thrive more in the on-site work place and others in remote jobs.The most important thing is to give your best, explore your full potential and make the most of the opportunity you have.Things to look out for whether Remote or on-site. 1ï¸âƒ£Taking ownership of your work and projects2ï¸âƒ£Comfort, make sure you're happy doing your job, if not please take neccessary actions.3ï¸âƒ£Work-life balance,  Easily balance work and personal responsibilities, improving overall well-being and not burn out.If we all know this, everyone will be happy to make the most of what they have currently. Well, which would you go for, and why?share your experiences with your job remote or on-site in the comments below!hashtag#RemoteJobs hashtag#WorkFromHome hashtag#Productivity hashtag#Motivation hashtag#SelfCare hashtag#JobSearch hashtag#CareerAdvice

What I Automated This Week â€” and Saved 2 Hours WeeklyOne of my personal goals as a DevOps engineer is to eliminate repetitive manual tasks â€” not just for myself, but for the whole team.This week I automated something small, but annoying: âŒ manually building Docker images âŒ logging into the registry âŒ pushing images âŒ double-checking version tagsNow, GitLab CI does it all for me: âœ… automatically builds Docker images âœ… logs into the private registry using GitLab CI secrets âœ… pushes images on merge or tag âœ… tags them using git describe + commit hashWhat did I get from this? ğŸ•’ saved around 2 hours per week âœ… less chance to miss a step ğŸš€ it's set-and-forget â€” I just push, and it fliesBonus tips that helped me: - use rules: to run only on merge to main - use before_script to log in securely with secrets - use CI_COMMIT_TAG and CI_COMMIT_REF_NAME for dynamic versioningIf you're interested, I can share a full .gitlab-ci.yml snippet with comments and tricks I use.ğŸ’¬ Whatâ€™s the last thing you automated that made your life easier? Even small changes can save you hours â€” share yours!

Here's why you must be careful of wanting to land a remote job?Many persons desire to work form home,infact we now see it as a flex.I mean, you can be in your PJ, with your juice by the side... yet you're doing the work.isn't that great?Well in reality, it's not always like that.Working from home requires discipline, motivation, and a lot more.-Can you stay motivated and focused without direct supervision?- Are you comfortable with minimal social interaction and human connection?- Can you establish clear boundaries between work and personal life?Ask Yourself all these before wanting a remote job.ğŸ”¹ï¸Now to my 9-5 workersThat you do the everyday 9-5 job does not make you a failure.There are people who thrive more in the on-site work place and others in remote jobs.The most important thing is to give your best, explore your full potential and make the most of the opportunity you have.Things to look out for whether Remote or on-site. 1ï¸âƒ£Taking ownership of your work and projects2ï¸âƒ£Comfort, make sure you're happy doing your job, if not please take neccessary actions.3ï¸âƒ£Work-life balance,  Easily balance work and personal responsibilities, improving overall well-being and not burn out.If we all know this, everyone will be happy to make the most of what they have currently. Well, which would you go for, and why?share your experiences with your job remote or on-site in the comments below!hashtag#RemoteJobs hashtag#WorkFromHome hashtag#Productivity hashtag#Motivation hashtag#SelfCare hashtag#JobSearch hashtag#CareerAdvice

What I Automated This Week â€” and Saved 2 Hours WeeklyOne of my personal goals as a DevOps engineer is to eliminate repetitive manual tasks â€” not just for myself, but for the whole team.This week I automated something small, but annoying: âŒ manually building Docker images âŒ logging into the registry âŒ pushing images âŒ double-checking version tagsNow, GitLab CI does it all for me: âœ… automatically builds Docker images âœ… logs into the private registry using GitLab CI secrets âœ… pushes images on merge or tag âœ… tags them using git describe + commit hashWhat did I get from this? ğŸ•’ saved around 2 hours per week âœ… less chance to miss a step ğŸš€ it's set-and-forget â€” I just push, and it fliesBonus tips that helped me: - use rules: to run only on merge to main - use before_script to log in securely with secrets - use CI_COMMIT_TAG and CI_COMMIT_REF_NAME for dynamic versioningIf you're interested, I can share a full .gitlab-ci.yml snippet with comments and tricks I use.ğŸ’¬ Whatâ€™s the last thing you automated that made your life easier? Even small changes can save you hours â€” share yours!

Here's why you must be careful of wanting to land a remote job?Many persons desire to work form home,infact we now see it as a flex.I mean, you can be in your PJ, with your juice by the side... yet you're doing the work.isn't that great?Well in reality, it's not always like that.Working from home requires discipline, motivation, and a lot more.-Can you stay motivated and focused without direct supervision?- Are you comfortable with minimal social interaction and human connection?- Can you establish clear boundaries between work and personal life?Ask Yourself all these before wanting a remote job.ğŸ”¹ï¸Now to my 9-5 workersThat you do the everyday 9-5 job does not make you a failure.There are people who thrive more in the on-site work place and others in remote jobs.The most important thing is to give your best, explore your full potential and make the most of the opportunity you have.Things to look out for whether Remote or on-site. 1ï¸âƒ£Taking ownership of your work and projects2ï¸âƒ£Comfort, make sure you're happy doing your job, if not please take neccessary actions.3ï¸âƒ£Work-life balance,  Easily balance work and personal responsibilities, improving overall well-being and not burn out.If we all know this, everyone will be happy to make the most of what they have currently. Well, which would you go for, and why?share your experiences with your job remote or on-site in the comments below!hashtag#RemoteJobs hashtag#WorkFromHome hashtag#Productivity hashtag#Motivation hashtag#SelfCare hashtag#JobSearch hashtag#CareerAdvice

Implement and deliver validation processes ensuring regulatory compliance across the SDLC.  Demonstrate good writing and editing skills in creating solution delivery documents, including executive presentations, and marketing material.  Define and integrate BA practices across the SDLC lifecycle to optimize solution delivery.  Contribute to teamwork across diverse groups and the BA community. What I Automated This Week â€” and Saved 2 Hours WeeklyOne of my personal goals as a DevOps engineer is to eliminate repetitive manual tasks â€” not just for myself, but for the whole team.This week I automated something small, but annoying: âŒ manually building Docker images âŒ logging into the registry âŒ pushing images âŒ double-checking version tagsNow, GitLab CI does it all for me: âœ… automatically builds Docker images âœ… logs into the private registry using GitLab CI secrets âœ… pushes images on merge or tag âœ… tags them using git describe + commit hashWhat did I get from this? ğŸ•’ saved around 2 hours per week âœ… less chance to miss a step ğŸš€ it's set-and-forget â€” I just push, and it fliesBonus tips that helped me: - use rules: to run only on merge to main - use before_script to log in securely with secrets - use CI_COMMIT_TAG and CI_COMMIT_REF_NAME for dynamic versioningIf you're interested, I can share a full .gitlab-ci.yml snippet with comments and tricks I use.ğŸ’¬ Whatâ€™s the last thing you automated that made your life easier? Even small changes can save you hours â€” share yours!

Here's why you must be careful of wanting to land a remote job?Many persons desire to work form home,infact we now see it as a flex.I mean, you can be in your PJ, with your juice by the side... yet you're doing the work.isn't that great?Well in reality, it's not always like that.Working from home requires discipline, motivation, and a lot more.-Can you stay motivated and focused without direct supervision?- Are you comfortable with minimal social interaction and human connection?- Can you establish clear boundaries between work and personal life?Ask Yourself all these before wanting a remote job.ğŸ”¹ï¸Now to my 9-5 workersThat you do the everyday 9-5 job does not make you a failure.There are people who thrive more in the on-site work place and others in remote jobs.The most important thing is to give your best, explore your full potential and make the most of the opportunity you have.Things to look out for whether Remote or on-site. 1ï¸âƒ£Taking ownership of your work and projects2ï¸âƒ£Comfort, make sure you're happy doing your job, if not please take neccessary actions.3ï¸âƒ£Work-life balance,  Easily balance work and personal responsibilities, improving overall well-being and not burn out.If we all know this, everyone will be happy to make the most of what they have currently. Well, which would you go for, and why?share your experiences with your job remote or on-site in the comments below!hashtag#RemoteJobs hashtag#WorkFromHome hashtag#Productivity hashtag#Motivation hashtag#SelfCare hashtag#JobSearch hashtag#CareerAdvice

What I Automated This Week â€” and Saved 2 Hours WeeklyOne of my personal goals as a DevOps engineer is to eliminate repetitive manual tasks â€” not just for myself, but for the whole team.This week I automated something small, but annoying: âŒ manually building Docker images âŒ logging into the registry âŒ pushing images âŒ double-checking version tagsNow, GitLab CI does it all for me: âœ… automatically builds Docker images âœ… logs into the private registry using GitLab CI secrets âœ… pushes images on merge or tag âœ… tags them using git describe + commit hashWhat did I get from this? ğŸ•’ saved around 2 hours per week âœ… less chance to miss a step ğŸš€ it's set-and-forget â€” I just push, and it fliesBonus tips that helped me: - use rules: to run only on merge to main - use before_script to log in securely with secrets - use CI_COMMIT_TAG and CI_COMMIT_REF_NAME for dynamic versioningIf you're interested, I can share a full .gitlab-ci.yml snippet with comments and tricks I use.ğŸ’¬ Whatâ€™s the last thing you automated that made your life easier? Even small changes can save you hours â€” share yours!

Here's why you must be careful of wanting to land a remote job?Many persons desire to work form home,infact we now see it as a flex.I mean, you can be in your PJ, with your juice by the side... yet you're doing the work.isn't that great?Well in reality, it's not always like that.Working from home requires discipline, motivation, and a lot more.-Can you stay motivated and focused without direct supervision?- Are you comfortable with minimal social interaction and human connection?- Can you establish clear boundaries between work and personal life?Ask Yourself all these before wanting a remote job.ğŸ”¹ï¸Now to my 9-5 workersThat you do the everyday 9-5 job does not make you a failure.There are people who thrive more in the on-site work place and others in remote jobs.The most important thing is to give your best, explore your full potential and make the most of the opportunity you have.Things to look out for whether Remote or on-site. 1ï¸âƒ£Taking ownership of your work and projects2ï¸âƒ£Comfort, make sure you're happy doing your job, if not please take neccessary actions.3ï¸âƒ£Work-life balance,  Easily balance work and personal responsibilities, improving overall well-being and not burn out.If we all know this, everyone will be happy to make the most of what they have currently. Well, which would you go for, and why?share your experiences with your job remote or on-site in the comments below!hashtag#RemoteJobs hashtag#WorkFromHome hashtag#Productivity hashtag#Motivation hashtag#SelfCare hashtag#JobSearch hashtag#CareerAdvice

What I Automated This Week â€” and Saved 2 Hours WeeklyOne of my personal goals as a DevOps engineer is to eliminate repetitive manual tasks â€” not just for myself, but for the whole team.This week I automated something small, but annoying: âŒ manually building Docker images âŒ logging into the registry âŒ pushing images âŒ double-checking version tagsNow, GitLab CI does it all for me: âœ… automatically builds Docker images âœ… logs into the private registry using GitLab CI secrets âœ… pushes images on merge or tag âœ… tags them using git describe + commit hashWhat did I get from this? ğŸ•’ saved around 2 hours per week âœ… less chance to miss a step ğŸš€ it's set-and-forget â€” I just push, and it fliesBonus tips that helped me: - use rules: to run only on merge to main - use before_script to log in securely with secrets - use CI_COMMIT_TAG and CI_COMMIT_REF_NAME for dynamic versioningIf you're interested, I can share a full .gitlab-ci.yml snippet with comments and tricks I use.ğŸ’¬ Whatâ€™s the last thing you automated that made your life easier? Even small changes can save you hours â€” share yours!

Here's why you must be careful of wanting to land a remote job?Many persons desire to work form home,infact we now see it as a flex.I mean, you can be in your PJ, with your juice by the side... yet you're doing the work.isn't that great?Well in reality, it's not always like that.Working from home requires discipline, motivation, and a lot more.-Can you stay motivated and focused without direct supervision?- Are you comfortable with minimal social interaction and human connection?- Can you establish clear boundaries between work and personal life?Ask Yourself all these before wanting a remote job.ğŸ”¹ï¸Now to my 9-5 workersThat you do the everyday 9-5 job does not make you a failure.There are people who thrive more in the on-site work place and others in remote jobs.The most important thing is to give your best, explore your full potential and make the most of the opportunity you have.Things to look out for whether Remote or on-site. 1ï¸âƒ£Taking ownership of your work and projects2ï¸âƒ£Comfort, make sure you're happy doing your job, if not please take neccessary actions.3ï¸âƒ£Work-life balance,  Easily balance work and personal responsibilities, improving overall well-being and not burn out.If we all know this, everyone will be happy to make the most of what they have currently. Well, which would you go for, and why?share your experiences with your job remote or on-site in the comments below!hashtag#RemoteJobs hashtag#WorkFromHome hashtag#Productivity hashtag#Motivation hashtag#SelfCare hashtag#JobSearch hashtag#CareerAdvice

Implement and deliver validation processes ensuring regulatory compliance across the SDLC.  Demonstrate good writing and editing skills in creating solution delivery documents, including executive presentations, and marketing material.  Define and integrate BA practices across the SDLC lifecycle to optimize solution delivery.  Contribute to teamwork across diverse groups and the BA community. What I Automated This Week â€” and Saved 2 Hours WeeklyOne of my personal goals as a DevOps engineer is to eliminate repetitive manual tasks â€” not just for myself, but for the whole team.This week I automated something small, but annoying: âŒ manually building Docker images âŒ logging into the registry âŒ pushing images âŒ double-checking version tagsNow, GitLab CI does it all for me: âœ… automatically builds Docker images âœ… logs into the private registry using GitLab CI secrets âœ… pushes images on merge or tag âœ… tags them using git describe + commit hashWhat did I get from this? ğŸ•’ saved around 2 hours per week âœ… less chance to miss a step ğŸš€ it's set-and-forget â€” I just push, and it fliesBonus tips that helped me: - use rules: to run only on merge to main - use before_script to log in securely with secrets - use CI_COMMIT_TAG and CI_COMMIT_REF_NAME for dynamic versioningIf you're interested, I can share a full .gitlab-ci.yml snippet with comments and tricks I use.ğŸ’¬ Whatâ€™s the last thing you automated that made your life easier? Even small changes can save you hours â€” share yours!

Here's why you must be careful of wanting to land a remote job?Many persons desire to work form home,infact we now see it as a flex.I mean, you can be in your PJ, with your juice by the side... yet you're doing the work.isn't that great?Well in reality, it's not always like that.Working from home requires discipline, motivation, and a lot more.-Can you stay motivated and focused without direct supervision?- Are you comfortable with minimal social interaction and human connection?- Can you establish clear boundaries between work and personal life?Ask Yourself all these before wanting a remote job.ğŸ”¹ï¸Now to my 9-5 workersThat you do the everyday 9-5 job does not make you a failure.There are people who thrive more in the on-site work place and others in remote jobs.The most important thing is to give your best, explore your full potential and make the most of the opportunity you have.Things to look out for whether Remote or on-site. 1ï¸âƒ£Taking ownership of your work and projects2ï¸âƒ£Comfort, make sure you're happy doing your job, if not please take neccessary actions.3ï¸âƒ£Work-life balance,  Easily balance work and personal responsibilities, improving overall well-being and not burn out.If we all know this, everyone will be happy to make the most of what they have currently. Well, which would you go for, and why?share your experiences with your job remote or on-site in the comments below!hashtag#RemoteJobs hashtag#WorkFromHome hashtag#Productivity hashtag#Motivation hashtag#SelfCare hashtag#JobSearch hashtag#CareerAdvice

What I Automated This Week â€” and Saved 2 Hours WeeklyOne of my personal goals as a DevOps engineer is to eliminate repetitive manual tasks â€” not just for myself, but for the whole team.This week I automated something small, but annoying: âŒ manually building Docker images âŒ logging into the registry âŒ pushing images âŒ double-checking version tagsNow, GitLab CI does it all for me: âœ… automatically builds Docker images âœ… logs into the private registry using GitLab CI secrets âœ… pushes images on merge or tag âœ… tags them using git describe + commit hashWhat did I get from this? ğŸ•’ saved around 2 hours per week âœ… less chance to miss a step ğŸš€ it's set-and-forget â€” I just push, and it fliesBonus tips that helped me: - use rules: to run only on merge to main - use before_script to log in securely with secrets - use CI_COMMIT_TAG and CI_COMMIT_REF_NAME for dynamic versioningIf you're interested, I can share a full .gitlab-ci.yml snippet with comments and tricks I use.ğŸ’¬ Whatâ€™s the last thing you automated that made your life easier? Even small changes can save you hours â€” share yours!

Here's why you must be careful of wanting to land a remote job?Many persons desire to work form home,infact we now see it as a flex.I mean, you can be in your PJ, with your juice by the side... yet you're doing the work.isn't that great?Well in reality, it's not always like that.Working from home requires discipline, motivation, and a lot more.-Can you stay motivated and focused without direct supervision?- Are you comfortable with minimal social interaction and human connection?- Can you establish clear boundaries between work and personal life?Ask Yourself all these before wanting a remote job.ğŸ”¹ï¸Now to my 9-5 workersThat you do the everyday 9-5 job does not make you a failure.There are people who thrive more in the on-site work place and others in remote jobs.The most important thing is to give your best, explore your full potential and make the most of the opportunity you have.Things to look out for whether Remote or on-site. 1ï¸âƒ£Taking ownership of your work and projects2ï¸âƒ£Comfort, make sure you're happy doing your job, if not please take neccessary actions.3ï¸âƒ£Work-life balance,  Easily balance work and personal responsibilities, improving overall well-being and not burn out.If we all know this, everyone will be happy to make the most of what they have currently. Well, which would you go for, and why?share your experiences with your job remote or on-site in the comments below!hashtag#RemoteJobs hashtag#WorkFromHome hashtag#Productivity hashtag#Motivation hashtag#SelfCare hashtag#JobSearch hashtag#CareerAdvice

What I Automated This Week â€” and Saved 2 Hours WeeklyOne of my personal goals as a DevOps engineer is to eliminate repetitive manual tasks â€” not just for myself, but for the whole team.This week I automated something small, but annoying: âŒ manually building Docker images âŒ logging into the registry âŒ pushing images âŒ double-checking version tagsNow, GitLab CI does it all for me: âœ… automatically builds Docker images âœ… logs into the private registry using GitLab CI secrets âœ… pushes images on merge or tag âœ… tags them using git describe + commit hashWhat did I get from this? ğŸ•’ saved around 2 hours per week âœ… less chance to miss a step ğŸš€ it's set-and-forget â€” I just push, and it fliesBonus tips that helped me: - use rules: to run only on merge to main - use before_script to log in securely with secrets - use CI_COMMIT_TAG and CI_COMMIT_REF_NAME for dynamic versioningIf you're interested, I can share a full .gitlab-ci.yml snippet with comments and tricks I use.ğŸ’¬ Whatâ€™s the last thing you automated that made your life easier? Even small changes can save you hours â€” share yours!

Here's why you must be careful of wanting to land a remote job?Many persons desire to work form home,infact we now see it as a flex.I mean, you can be in your PJ, with your juice by the side... yet you're doing the work.isn't that great?Well in reality, it's not always like that.Working from home requires discipline, motivation, and a lot more.-Can you stay motivated and focused without direct supervision?- Are you comfortable with minimal social interaction and human connection?- Can you establish clear boundaries between work and personal life?Ask Yourself all these before wanting a remote job.ğŸ”¹ï¸Now to my 9-5 workersThat you do the everyday 9-5 job does not make you a failure.There are people who thrive more in the on-site work place and others in remote jobs.The most important thing is to give your best, explore your full potential and make the most of the opportunity you have.Things to look out for whether Remote or on-site. 1ï¸âƒ£Taking ownership of your work and projects2ï¸âƒ£Comfort, make sure you're happy doing your job, if not please take neccessary actions.3ï¸âƒ£Work-life balance,  Easily balance work and personal responsibilities, improving overall well-being and not burn out.If we all know this, everyone will be happy to make the most of what they have currently. Well, which would you go for, and why?share your experiences with your job remote or on-site in the comments below!hashtag#RemoteJobs hashtag#WorkFromHome hashtag#Productivity hashtag#Motivation hashtag#SelfCare hashtag#JobSearch hashtag#CareerAdvice

Implement and deliver validation processes ensuring regulatory compliance across the SDLC.  Demonstrate good writing and editing skills in creating solution delivery documents, including executive presentations, and marketing material.  Define and integrate BA practices across the SDLC lifecycle to optimize solution delivery.  Contribute to teamwork across diverse groups and the BA community. What I Automated This Week â€” and Saved 2 Hours WeeklyOne of my personal goals as a DevOps engineer is to eliminate repetitive manual tasks â€” not just for myself, but for the whole team.This week I automated something small, but annoying: âŒ manually building Docker images âŒ logging into the registry âŒ pushing images âŒ double-checking version tagsNow, GitLab CI does it all for me: âœ… automatically builds Docker images âœ… logs into the private registry using GitLab CI secrets âœ… pushes images on merge or tag âœ… tags them using git describe + commit hashWhat did I get from this? ğŸ•’ saved around 2 hours per week âœ… less chance to miss a step ğŸš€ it's set-and-forget â€” I just push, and it fliesBonus tips that helped me: - use rules: to run only on merge to main - use before_script to log in securely with secrets - use CI_COMMIT_TAG and CI_COMMIT_REF_NAME for dynamic versioningIf you're interested, I can share a full .gitlab-ci.yml snippet with comments and tricks I use.ğŸ’¬ Whatâ€™s the last thing you automated that made your life easier? Even small changes can save you hours â€” share yours!

Here's why you must be careful of wanting to land a remote job?Many persons desire to work form home,infact we now see it as a flex.I mean, you can be in your PJ, with your juice by the side... yet you're doing the work.isn't that great?Well in reality, it's not always like that.Working from home requires discipline, motivation, and a lot more.-Can you stay motivated and focused without direct supervision?- Are you comfortable with minimal social interaction and human connection?- Can you establish clear boundaries between work and personal life?Ask Yourself all these before wanting a remote job.ğŸ”¹ï¸Now to my 9-5 workersThat you do the everyday 9-5 job does not make you a failure.There are people who thrive more in the on-site work place and others in remote jobs.The most important thing is to give your best, explore your full potential and make the most of the opportunity you have.Things to look out for whether Remote or on-site. 1ï¸âƒ£Taking ownership of your work and projects2ï¸âƒ£Comfort, make sure you're happy doing your job, if not please take neccessary actions.3ï¸âƒ£Work-life balance,  Easily balance work and personal responsibilities, improving overall well-being and not burn out.If we all know this, everyone will be happy to make the most of what they have currently. Well, which would you go for, and why?share your experiences with your job remote or on-site in the comments below!hashtag#RemoteJobs hashtag#WorkFromHome hashtag#Productivity hashtag#Motivation hashtag#SelfCare hashtag#JobSearch hashtag#CareerAdvice

What I Automated This Week â€” and Saved 2 Hours WeeklyOne of my personal goals as a DevOps engineer is to eliminate repetitive manual tasks â€” not just for myself, but for the whole team.This week I automated something small, but annoying: âŒ manually building Docker images âŒ logging into the registry âŒ pushing images âŒ double-checking version tagsNow, GitLab CI does it all for me: âœ… automatically builds Docker images âœ… logs into the private registry using GitLab CI secrets âœ… pushes images on merge or tag âœ… tags them using git describe + commit hashWhat did I get from this? ğŸ•’ saved around 2 hours per week âœ… less chance to miss a step ğŸš€ it's set-and-forget â€” I just push, and it fliesBonus tips that helped me: - use rules: to run only on merge to main - use before_script to log in securely with secrets - use CI_COMMIT_TAG and CI_COMMIT_REF_NAME for dynamic versioningIf you're interested, I can share a full .gitlab-ci.yml snippet with comments and tricks I use.ğŸ’¬ Whatâ€™s the last thing you automated that made your life easier? Even small changes can save you hours â€” share yours!

Here's why you must be careful of wanting to land a remote job?Many persons desire to work form home,infact we now see it as a flex.I mean, you can be in your PJ, with your juice by the side... yet you're doing the work.isn't that great?Well in reality, it's not always like that.Working from home requires discipline, motivation, and a lot more.-Can you stay motivated and focused without direct supervision?- Are you comfortable with minimal social interaction and human connection?- Can you establish clear boundaries between work and personal life?Ask Yourself all these before wanting a remote job.ğŸ”¹ï¸Now to my 9-5 workersThat you do the everyday 9-5 job does not make you a failure.There are people who thrive more in the on-site work place and others in remote jobs.The most important thing is to give your best, explore your full potential and make the most of the opportunity you have.Things to look out for whether Remote or on-site. 1ï¸âƒ£Taking ownership of your work and projects2ï¸âƒ£Comfort, make sure you're happy doing your job, if not please take neccessary actions.3ï¸âƒ£Work-life balance,  Easily balance work and personal responsibilities, improving overall well-being and not burn out.If we all know this, everyone will be happy to make the most of what they have currently. Well, which would you go for, and why?share your experiences with your job remote or on-site in the comments below!hashtag#RemoteJobs hashtag#WorkFromHome hashtag#Productivity hashtag#Motivation hashtag#SelfCare hashtag#JobSearch hashtag#CareerAdvice

What I Automated This Week â€” and Saved 2 Hours WeeklyOne of my personal goals as a DevOps engineer is to eliminate repetitive manual tasks â€” not just for myself, but for the whole team.This week I automated something small, but annoying: âŒ manually building Docker images âŒ logging into the registry âŒ pushing images âŒ double-checking version tagsNow, GitLab CI does it all for me: âœ… automatically builds Docker images âœ… logs into the private registry using GitLab CI secrets âœ… pushes images on merge or tag âœ… tags them using git describe + commit hashWhat did I get from this? ğŸ•’ saved around 2 hours per week âœ… less chance to miss a step ğŸš€ it's set-and-forget â€” I just push, and it fliesBonus tips that helped me: - use rules: to run only on merge to main - use before_script to log in securely with secrets - use CI_COMMIT_TAG and CI_COMMIT_REF_NAME for dynamic versioningIf you're interested, I can share a full .gitlab-ci.yml snippet with comments and tricks I use.ğŸ’¬ Whatâ€™s the last thing you automated that made your life easier? Even small changes can save you hours â€” share yours!

Here's why you must be careful of wanting to land a remote job?Many persons desire to work form home,infact we now see it as a flex.I mean, you can be in your PJ, with your juice by the side... yet you're doing the work.isn't that great?Well in reality, it's not always like that.Working from home requires discipline, motivation, and a lot more.-Can you stay motivated and focused without direct supervision?- Are you comfortable with minimal social interaction and human connection?- Can you establish clear boundaries between work and personal life?Ask Yourself all these before wanting a remote job.ğŸ”¹ï¸Now to my 9-5 workersThat you do the everyday 9-5 job does not make you a failure.There are people who thrive more in the on-site work place and others in remote jobs.The most important thing is to give your best, explore your full potential and make the most of the opportunity you have.Things to look out for whether Remote or on-site. 1ï¸âƒ£Taking ownership of your work and projects2ï¸âƒ£Comfort, make sure you're happy doing your job, if not please take neccessary actions.3ï¸âƒ£Work-life balance,  Easily balance work and personal responsibilities, improving overall well-being and not burn out.If we all know this, everyone will be happy to make the most of what they have currently. Well, which would you go for, and why?share your experiences with your job remote or on-site in the comments below!hashtag#RemoteJobs hashtag#WorkFromHome hashtag#Productivity hashtag#Motivation hashtag#SelfCare hashtag#JobSearch hashtag#CareerAdvice

Implement and deliver validation processes ensuring regulatory compliance across the SDLC.  Demonstrate good writing and editing skills in creating solution delivery documents, including executive presentations, and marketing material.  Define and integrate BA practices across the SDLC lifecycle to optimize solution delivery.  Contribute to teamwork across diverse groups and the BA community. What I Automated This Week â€” and Saved 2 Hours WeeklyOne of my personal goals as a DevOps engineer is to eliminate repetitive manual tasks â€” not just for myself, but for the whole team.This week I automated something small, but annoying: âŒ manually building Docker images âŒ logging into the registry âŒ pushing images âŒ double-checking version tagsNow, GitLab CI does it all for me: âœ… automatically builds Docker images âœ… logs into the private registry using GitLab CI secrets âœ… pushes images on merge or tag âœ… tags them using git describe + commit hashWhat did I get from this? ğŸ•’ saved around 2 hours per week âœ… less chance to miss a step ğŸš€ it's set-and-forget â€” I just push, and it fliesBonus tips that helped me: - use rules: to run only on merge to main - use before_script to log in securely with secrets - use CI_COMMIT_TAG and CI_COMMIT_REF_NAME for dynamic versioningIf you're interested, I can share a full .gitlab-ci.yml snippet with comments and tricks I use.ğŸ’¬ Whatâ€™s the last thing you automated that made your life easier? Even small changes can save you hours â€” share yours!

Here's why you must be careful of wanting to land a remote job?Many persons desire to work form home,infact we now see it as a flex.I mean, you can be in your PJ, with your juice by the side... yet you're doing the work.isn't that great?Well in reality, it's not always like that.Working from home requires discipline, motivation, and a lot more.-Can you stay motivated and focused without direct supervision?- Are you comfortable with minimal social interaction and human connection?- Can you establish clear boundaries between work and personal life?Ask Yourself all these before wanting a remote job.ğŸ”¹ï¸Now to my 9-5 workersThat you do the everyday 9-5 job does not make you a failure.There are people who thrive more in the on-site work place and others in remote jobs.The most important thing is to give your best, explore your full potential and make the most of the opportunity you have.Things to look out for whether Remote or on-site. 1ï¸âƒ£Taking ownership of your work and projects2ï¸âƒ£Comfort, make sure you're happy doing your job, if not please take neccessary actions.3ï¸âƒ£Work-life balance,  Easily balance work and personal responsibilities, improving overall well-being and not burn out.If we all know this, everyone will be happy to make the most of what they have currently. Well, which would you go for, and why?share your experiences with your job remote or on-site in the comments below!hashtag#RemoteJobs hashtag#WorkFromHome hashtag#Productivity hashtag#Motivation hashtag#SelfCare hashtag#JobSearch hashtag#CareerAdvice

What I Automated This Week â€” and Saved 2 Hours WeeklyOne of my personal goals as a DevOps engineer is to eliminate repetitive manual tasks â€” not just for myself, but for the whole team.This week I automated something small, but annoying: âŒ manually building Docker images âŒ logging into the registry âŒ pushing images âŒ double-checking version tagsNow, GitLab CI does it all for me: âœ… automatically builds Docker images âœ… logs into the private registry using GitLab CI secrets âœ… pushes images on merge or tag âœ… tags them using git describe + commit hashWhat did I get from this? ğŸ•’ saved around 2 hours per week âœ… less chance to miss a step ğŸš€ it's set-and-forget â€” I just push, and it fliesBonus tips that helped me: - use rules: to run only on merge to main - use before_script to log in securely with secrets - use CI_COMMIT_TAG and CI_COMMIT_REF_NAME for dynamic versioningIf you're interested, I can share a full .gitlab-ci.yml snippet with comments and tricks I use.ğŸ’¬ Whatâ€™s the last thing you automated that made your life easier? Even small changes can save you hours â€” share yours!

Here's why you must be careful of wanting to land a remote job?Many persons desire to work form home,infact we now see it as a flex.I mean, you can be in your PJ, with your juice by the side... yet you're doing the work.isn't that great?Well in reality, it's not always like that.Working from home requires discipline, motivation, and a lot more.-Can you stay motivated and focused without direct supervision?- Are you comfortable with minimal social interaction and human connection?- Can you establish clear boundaries between work and personal life?Ask Yourself all these before wanting a remote job.ğŸ”¹ï¸Now to my 9-5 workersThat you do the everyday 9-5 job does not make you a failure.There are people who thrive more in the on-site work place and others in remote jobs.The most important thing is to give your best, explore your full potential and make the most of the opportunity you have.Things to look out for whether Remote or on-site. 1ï¸âƒ£Taking ownership of your work and projects2ï¸âƒ£Comfort, make sure you're happy doing your job, if not please take neccessary actions.3ï¸âƒ£Work-life balance,  Easily balance work and personal responsibilities, improving overall well-being and not burn out.If we all know this, everyone will be happy to make the most of what they have currently. Well, which would you go for, and why?share your experiences with your job remote or on-site in the comments below!hashtag#RemoteJobs hashtag#WorkFromHome hashtag#Productivity hashtag#Motivation hashtag#SelfCare hashtag#JobSearch hashtag#CareerAdvice

What I Automated This Week â€” and Saved 2 Hours WeeklyOne of my personal goals as a DevOps engineer is to eliminate repetitive manual tasks â€” not just for myself, but for the whole team.This week I automated something small, but annoying: âŒ manually building Docker images âŒ logging into the registry âŒ pushing images âŒ double-checking version tagsNow, GitLab CI does it all for me: âœ… automatically builds Docker images âœ… logs into the private registry using GitLab CI secrets âœ… pushes images on merge or tag âœ… tags them using git describe + commit hashWhat did I get from this? ğŸ•’ saved around 2 hours per week âœ… less chance to miss a step ğŸš€ it's set-and-forget â€” I just push, and it fliesBonus tips that helped me: - use rules: to run only on merge to main - use before_script to log in securely with secrets - use CI_COMMIT_TAG and CI_COMMIT_REF_NAME for dynamic versioningIf you're interested, I can share a full .gitlab-ci.yml snippet with comments and tricks I use.ğŸ’¬ Whatâ€™s the last thing you automated that made your life easier? Even small changes can save you hours â€” share yours!

Here's why you must be careful of wanting to land a remote job?Many persons desire to work form home,infact we now see it as a flex.I mean, you can be in your PJ, with your juice by the side... yet you're doing the work.isn't that great?Well in reality, it's not always like that.Working from home requires discipline, motivation, and a lot more.-Can you stay motivated and focused without direct supervision?- Are you comfortable with minimal social interaction and human connection?- Can you establish clear boundaries between work and personal life?Ask Yourself all these before wanting a remote job.ğŸ”¹ï¸Now to my 9-5 workersThat you do the everyday 9-5 job does not make you a failure.There are people who thrive more in the on-site work place and others in remote jobs.The most important thing is to give your best, explore your full potential and make the most of the opportunity you have.Things to look out for whether Remote or on-site. 1ï¸âƒ£Taking ownership of your work and projects2ï¸âƒ£Comfort, make sure you're happy doing your job, if not please take neccessary actions.3ï¸âƒ£Work-life balance,  Easily balance work and personal responsibilities, improving overall well-being and not burn out.If we all know this, everyone will be happy to make the most of what they have currently. Well, which would you go for, and why?share your experiences with your job remote or on-site in the comments below!hashtag#RemoteJobs hashtag#WorkFromHome hashtag#Productivity hashtag#Motivation hashtag#SelfCare hashtag#JobSearch hashtag#CareerAdvice
